#Text=Soviet human rights activist Yelena Bonner dies aged 88
#Text=Tuesday , June 21 , 2011
#Text=File : BonnerAndSakharovAndKallistratova1986 . jpg
#Text=Yelena Bonner ( left ) , Andrei Sakharov and Sofiya Kalistratova in Moscow , 1977 .
#Text=( Image missing from commons : image ; log )
#Text=Soviet human rights activist Yelena Bonner died of heart failure in Boston , Massachusetts on Saturday at the age of 88 , her daughter Tatiana Yankelevich said in a statement .
#Text=She had been hospitalized since February 21 .

#Text=Bonner gained fame by smuggling the papers of her late husband , the nuclear physicist and Russian dissident Andrei Sakharov , out of Siberia and was prominent in her own right for her human rights activism .
#Text=Leaders and politicians paid Bonner tribute .
#Text=" The world has lost one of the most inspiring and dedicated human rights defenders , " said Jerzy Buzek , President of the European Parliament .
#Text=The world has lost one of the most inspiring and dedicated human rights defenders . — Jerzy Buzek , President European Parliament

#Text=Bonner was born in Turkmenistan February 15 , 1923 to a family of Communist Party officials ; her father was later killed and her mother sent to a gulag in Joseph Stalin 's purges of the late 1930s .
#Text=In 1941 , she became a nurse for the Soviet military on the front during World War II .
#Text=She suffered a severe wound to the chest , and serious head injuries in 1943 from which she nearly lost her sight , and received decorations for valor .
#Text=Bonner returned to the front in 1945 , advancing with the army to Potsdam .
#Text=While studying medicine when the war was over , she married a fellow student , Ivan Semyonov and they had a son and a daughter .
#Text=But as she became increasingly politically active , they lost their common interests and divorced in 1965 .
#Text=She was an active Soviet dissident in the 1970s , and a leader of a group that monitored Soviet compliance with the Helsinki Accords .
#Text=The Washington Post describes her at this time as " [ h]eadstrong and sharp-tongued with a no-nonsense voice deepened by years of chain-smoking acrid Russian cigarettes " .
#Text=Bonner married Sakharov in 1972 , whom she had met through her political activities .

#Text=He was also fierce critic of the lack of civil liberties and human rights in the Soviet Union , and their tiny Moscow apartment became the meeting place for the Soviet dissident movement in the 1970s .
#Text=They traveled around Russia together visiting imprisoned dissidents and working for their legal rights .
#Text=When Sakharov won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1975 , she traveled to Oslo to receive it on his behalf as Soviet authorities refused to allow her husband to leave the country .
#Text=We note with profound sadness the death of Yelena Bonner , an extraordinary voice among human rights defenders in the former Soviet Union and the Russian Federation .
#Text=— Victoria Nuland , U.S. State Department
#Text=Sakharove was arrested in 1980 and exiled to Siberia , and Bonner , Sakharove 's sole contact with the outside world , smuggled his writings to Moscow and ensured that they were published .
#Text=Soviet authorities conducted campaigns of personal attacks against her , accusing her of being a foreign agent who turned Sakharove against his country .
#Text=In 1984 she was convicted of " anti-Soviet agitation " and was exiled to Siberia with her husband , both continually harassed by authorities .
#Text=She published her memoir in 1986 of the years in exile , described by the Washington Post as partly " a love story of mutual sacrifice . "
#Text=In 1986 Mikhail Gorbachev allowed the Sakharoves to return to Moscow where they continued to agitate for human rights and were constantly harassed for their activities .
#Text=When the Soviet Union collapsed two years after Sakharov 's death in 1989 , Bonner continued her human rights and political activities .
#Text=She initially supported President Boris Yeltsin 's government and served on his state human rights commission , but became critical of his government at the beginning of the war in Chechnya .
#Text=She was also critical of Yeltin 's successor , Vladimir Putin , and was the first person to sign a petition against him in March 2010 .
#Text=As her health deteriorated , she became less active , and she moved to the United States to be with her daughter .
#Text=Bonner received the Rafto Prize in 1991 for her promotion of human rights in the former Soviet Union and in contemporary Russia .
#Text=She published at least four books and edited her husband 's memoirs which were published in 1997 .

#Text=U.S. State Department 's spokesperson Victoria Nuland said in a statement : " We note with profound sadness the death of Yelena Bonner , an extraordinary voice among human rights defenders in the former Soviet Union and the Russian Federation . "
